journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: An investigation of the strain rate and temperature effects on the plastic flow stress and ductile failure strain of aluminum alloys 5083-H116, 6082-T6 and a 5183 weld metal

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH, USA
2Alloy Development and Mechanics Branch, Naval Surface Warfare Center, West Bethesda, MD, USA

author-notes.corresp: Xiaosheng Gao, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325, USA. Email: xgao@uakron.edu

abstract.p: This article presents a comprehensive experimental and numerical study to investigate the effects of strain rate and temperature on flow stress and ductile failure strain of three aluminum alloys. The test matrix includes smooth and notched round tensile specimens tested at room temperature (24 ℃) and two elevated temperatures (66 ℃ and 149 ℃), and under different strain rates. For 5083-H116, three loading rates are considered at 24 ℃ and it is found that the flow stress and failure strain are lowest at the intermediate strain rate. At high strain rate, the flow stresses of 5083-H116 and 6082-T6 are higher than the quasi-static loading while the flow stress of the 5183 weld metal remains unchanged; the ductility of the 5XXX alloys shows a significant increase compared to the quasi-static loading while the ductility of 6082-T6 does not change much. The study indicates that the Johnson–Cook plasticity and fracture models can be used to describe the temperature dependencies of the flow stress and the failure strain for 6082-T6 but not the 5XXX alloys. At 66 ℃ the 5XXX alloys do not display temperature softening compared to 24 ℃ while their ductility is reduced. As temperature is elevated to 149 ℃, the flow stress of the 5XXX alloys decreases while the ductility increases. The unconventional behavior of the 5XXX alloys in certain temperature and strain rate ranges has been attributed to the dynamic strain aging effect. The study also suggests that the dependency of the failure strain on stress triaxiality can be described by the Johnson–Cook fracture model for all three materials under quasi-static loading at room temperature and the model parameters are calibrated using an inverse method combining experimental results with finite element analysis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aluminum alloys, because of their light weight, good mechanical properties and corrosion resistance, provide a viable replacement for steels in many engineering structures and these structures may be subjected to dynamic loading and experience varying temperature. Understanding the effects of strain rate and temperature on the plastic flow and ductility properties of these aluminum alloys is crucial to structural reliability assessments.

A number of literatures investigate the plastic flow and ductility properties of aluminum alloys under different strain rates and temperatures. Mukai et al.1 tested the strain rate effect on both flow and ductility behavior on high purity Al-Mg alloys with different magnesium concentrations. Naka et al.2 performed various temperature and strain rate tests on 5083-O. They also analyzed the ductility variation by measuring the elongations of the specimens. Usually the equivalent strain to failure is used as a measure of the material’s ductility, thus in structural analysis, the equivalent plastic strain is often used as the ductile failure criterion. A common method to get equivalent failure strain is by measuring the area reduction of round tensile specimen.3 This method is an approximate method for two reasons: one is that the fracture surface is often not a perfect circle, which causes difficulties in measuring the area reduction; another important reason is that the plastic flow becomes inhomogeneous after necking, which results in nonuniform strain distribution on the fracture surface. In this article, an inverse method is employed to obtain the local failure strain: by comparing the finite element simulated loading history with the experimental record, the equivalent strain at critical element when the failure initiated is extracted.

In finite element analysis (FEA), the plasticity model can be coupled or uncoupled with the damage/failure model, where the uncoupled model is adopted for simplicity in our study. A number of plasticity models with different function forms have been proposed to describe the strain rate and temperature effects on flow stress, among which the Johnson–Cook plasticity model4 is widely used because of its simplicity. In the Johnson–Cook model, the equivalent stress is expressed as the following function of the equivalent plastic strain ɛp, temperature T, and plastic strain rate ɛ·p (1)σeq=[A+Bɛpn][1+Cln(ɛ·pɛ·0)][1-(T-T0Tmelt-T0)q] where ɛ·0 is a reference plastic strain rate, T0 and Tmelt are the room temperature (RT) and the melting temperature respectively, and A, B, n, C and q are five material constants.

In the failure model, the failure strain does not only depend on the strain rate and temperature, but also on the stress state. Hancock and Mackenzie5 and Hancock and Brown6 have shown that the effective strain to initiate ductile fracture is a decaying function of the stress triaxiality defined as the ratio of the hydrostatic stress to the equivalent stress. Since then, an extensive amount of research efforts have been devoted to model the effect of stress state on ductile fracture.7–14 The Johnson–Cook fracture model,15 which is widely used in structural reliability analysis, provides a simple mathematical relation to describe the effects of stress triaxiality, strain rate and temperature on the equivalent strain to ductile fracture (2)ɛf=[D1+D2exp(D3σmσeq)][1+D4ln(ɛ·pɛ·0)] ×[1+D5(T-T0Tmelt-T0)] where ɛf represents the effective strain at ductile failure, σm represents the hydrostatic stress, and D1, D2, D3, D4 and D5 are five material constants.

This article presents a comprehensive experimental and numerical study to investigate the effects of strain rate and temperature on flow stress and ductile failure strain of three aluminum alloys, a 5083-H116, a 6082-T6 and a 5183 weld metal. In addition, the effect of the stress triaxiality on ductile failure strain is also studied. These materials are considered because they are the most often used aluminum alloys in marine structures. The test matrix includes smooth and notched round tensile specimens tested at RT (24 ℃) and two elevated temperatures (66 ℃ and 149 ℃), and under three levels of dynamic loading rates. Because 5083-H116 gains its strength from the work-hardening described by the H116 condition, the testing temperature of 149 ℃ is selected as the upper temperature for calibrating the thermal softening relation as it is safely below the hot-working temperature of 316 ℃. ‘Materials and experiments’ section provides detailed information about the materials and experimental procedures. ‘Plastic flow behavior’ section gives the plastic flow behavior of materials under different loading conditions. ‘Fracture behavior and numerical results’ section presents the fracture properties of materials and all the numerical results. And finally, the last section summarizes the major findings of this study.

sec.title: Materials and experiments
sec.p:
The aluminum alloys of interest are 5083-H116 (a work-hardened marine alloy), 6082-T6 (a precipitation hardened marine alloy), and welded joint of 5183 filler joining two 5083-H116 plates. 5083-H116 was procured in 25 mm thick rolled plate that is 1.2 m wide × 3.6 m long to ASTM B928-04 a from the Belaya Kalitva Metallurgical Products Company while 6082-T6 was procured in 25 mm thick × 0.2 m wide × 3.6 m long flat bars to ASTM B221 from Taber Extrusion, LLC. Base metal specimens were extracted from the center of the plate thickness in the transverse orientation, relative to the rolling direction. Chemical compositions of the three aluminum alloys are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Chemical compositions (wt%).
5083-H116 6082-T6 5183 weld metal
Al Balance Balance Balance
Si 0.20 1.01 0.40
Fe 0.35 0.31 0.40
Cu 0.052 0.09 0.10
Mn 0.69 0.40 0.5–1.0
Mg 4.41 0.61 4.3–5.2
Cr 0.086 0.02 0.05–0.25
Zn 0.081 0.02 0.25
Ti 0.065 0.03 0.15

Weldments were fabricated by Concurrent Technologies Corporation. The joint geometry is a single-V with a 6.35 mm root gap and a 60° groove angle, and designed such that the largest specimen geometry would be fully encapsulated by the weld metal. The plates were welded with a backing plate. All of the specimens from the welds were cut from the weld metal such that the gage section was fully composed of weld metal. These specimens were aligned along the weld axis. To facilitate this, a cross-section of each weldment was preferentially etched to delimit the weld metal from the base metal for ease of machining.

sec.title: Testing of smooth round bars
sec.p: The diameter of the gage section of the smooth round bars is 6.35 mm. RT, quasi-static (QS) tensile tests were conducted at a nominal strain rate of 10−3 s−1 in a computer-controlled servo-hydraulic test machine under actuator displacement control. Specimens were instrumented with a 25 mm extensometer and a diametral contraction gage. Elapsed time, actuator LVDT displacement, force from the machine load cell, extension, and diametral contraction were recorded at approximately 100 Hz.

Quasi-static, high temperature tensile tests at 66 ℃ and 149 ℃ were also conducted on a computer-controlled servo-hydraulic test machine under actuator displacement control at the same rates as RT tests and with the same data acquisition system. A specialized extensometer and a specialized diametral gage were employed for use at high temperature. Heating was achieved with an insulated electric furnace mounted about the load train. A type-K thermocouple mounted to the end of the specimen gage section enabled closed-loop temperature control within ±0.5 ℃.

For the quasi-static RT and high temperature tensile testing performed on the uniform gage specimens above, true stress was calculated using the load measurements and diametral contraction measurements until maximum load. After maximum load, necking occurs and there is no certainty that the diametral gage is located at the specimen minimum diameter. Consequently, from maximum load until fracture, true stress and true strain are not calculated. The fracture load is determined from the load–displacement curve where the load drops sharply with small increase in axial extension. It is at this point that fracture has initiated at the center of the specimen. Fracture stress is calculated with the fracture load and specimen post-mortem cross-section measurements and is adjusted using the Bridgman correction.16

True strain is calculated from diametral contraction data until maximum load. Fracture strain is calculated from cross-sectional measurements of the necked specimen. In some specimens, the final cross-section is not perfectly circular. For all specimens, post-mortem measurements were taken at multiple angles about the specimen axis, the minimum and maximum diameters at the neck are averaged, and the cross-sectional area is approximated as a circle using the average diameter. Differences between the area of a circle using the average of these diameters and the area of an ellipse using these diameters are less than 0.1% of the nominal original diameter.

Dynamic tensile tests at nominal strain rates up to 10 s−1 were performed on a unique servo-hydraulic test machine capable of applying loads of 20 kip (88.96 kN) at 5.08 m/s. At these high loading rates, the machine’s load cell does not adequately resolve load, nor would an extensometer or diametral gage maintain physical contact with the specimen throughout testing. Instead, the specimen design incorporates a larger diameter region than the gage section that is designed to remain elastic throughout testing. Two strain gages are applied 180° apart to this larger diameter region and wired in a Wheatstone half-bridge circuit to form an integral load cell. The integral load cell is calibrated to 10% of the predicted maximum load prior to testing and the calibration is extrapolated to full scale. Specimen axial strain measurement is achieved by applying two 3 mm high-elongation strain gages to the gage section of the specimen at 180° apart and also wired in a Wheatstone half-bridge. Figure 1 illustrates the dynamic specimen design. High-speed data acquisition was performed at 1 × 106 Hz on the machine’s LVDT, the integral load cell, and the strain gage signal from the gage section. Subsequent data reduction calculates true stress and true strain until the strain gages on the uniform gage section failed. True stress is calculated from engineering stress and true strain is calculated from engineering strain. Fracture stress and fracture strain are calculated the same as the QS specimens. Figure 1.
Schematic of dynamic, uniform tensile specimen (dimensions in mm).

sec.title: Testing of notched round bar
sec.p: Notched round tensile specimens impart higher stress triaxiality to the material in the gage section than the uniform tensile specimens. All the notched round bars have the same diameters of 15.2 mm in the smooth sections and 7.62 mm at the root of the notch so that the specimens sample the same amount of material. Three notch radii, 1.27 mm, 2.54 mm and 6.35 mm, are considered for specimens D, B and E, respectively. As the notch radius decreases, the stress triaxiality increases. Notched round bar tensile tests in the B-notch and E-notch configurations were conducted on the 5083-H116 base metal, 6082-T6 base metal, and 5183 weld metal at 10−3 s−1, 24 ℃. The D-notch specimens were tested only for the 5083-H116 base metal at 10−3 s−1, 24 ℃. Tests were conducted on the same servo-hydraulic load frame as the uniform tensile testing and data was acquired at 100 Hz. A 25 mm extensometer was centered about the gage section for each specimen and measured a global extension of the notched gage section. Fracture initiation is defined as when the load drops sharply with small increase in axial extension. The measured load versus axial displacement curves from these tests are compared to FEA results to determine the stress triaxiality and failure strain at the fracture initiation point (in the center of the notched cross-section).

sec.title: Strain hardening for room temperature, quasi-static loading
sec.p: It is found that the stress–strain relation at RT and QS loading can be very well described by a power-law function for all three materials, where the current yield stress is expressed as a power function of the total strain (3)σ=σ0(ɛɛ0)n asσ>σ0
Keeping other portion of the Johnson–Cook plasticity model unchanged, a modified Johnson–Cook plasticity model is adopted in this article (4)σeq=[σ0(ɛeqɛ0)n][1+Cln(ɛ·pɛ·0)][1-(T-T0Tmelt-T0)q]

In equation (3), σ0 represents the initial yield stress, ɛ is the total strain, ɛ0 is the initial yield strain (=σ0E, where E is the Young’s modulus) and n is the strain hardening exponent. Converting the measured engineering stress–strain curve to a true stress versus true strain curve and performing linear regression, one can obtain the strain hardening exponent, n. It is worth mentioning that only part of the experimental stress–strain data (from the yield point to the point of highest load) are used to calibrate the parameters in equations (3). Experimental records after necking starts are not used because of the inaccuracy of the stress and strain estimates after necking. The calibrated n-values are 0.17, 0.064 and 0.238 for 5083-H116, 6082-T6 and 5183 weld metal, respectively.

Figure 2 gives the stress–strain curves at various strain rates at RT for all three materials. From the stress–strain curves at QS loading rate given by Figure 2, material with a larger initial yield stress has a smaller strain hardening exponent n, and thus a flatter stress–strain curve. Figure 2.
Comparison of the stress–strain relations predicted by the Johnson–Cook model with experimental data at different strain rates: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 6082-T6; (c) 5183 weld metal.

sec.title: Strain rate effect on flow stress
sec.p: In the experiments, specimens were tested at three nominal strain rates, 0.001 s−1 (level 1), 0.1 s−1 (level 2) and 10 s−1 (level 3) and the 0.001 s−1 (level 1) rate was regarded as quasi-static. It is worth noting that the true plastic strain rates are different from these nominal rates.

The experimental records provide the time history of stress and strain, from which we can generate a true plastic strain versus time plot. Fitting this plot into a straight line, we can obtain the plastic strain rate (the slope of the straight line). Figure 3 illustrates the fitting process of one of the 5083-H116 specimen, of which the plastic strain rate is 0.0047. Table 2 lists the true plastic strain rates of all the specimens tested in this study. Figure 3.
Determination of the plastic strain rate.
Table 2.
Plastic strain rates of smooth round bars.
Nominal rate, 10−3 s−1 Nominal rate, 10−1 s−1 Nominal rate, 10 s−1
5083-H116 0.0045–0.0047 0.15–0.70 178–196
6082-T6 0.00503–0.00513 NA 167.1–220.4
5183 weld metal 0.00432–0.00437 NA 157.7–184.8

As shown in the Figure 2(a), the flow stress of 5083-H116 does not exhibit the same strain rate sensitivity in the test strain rate range. At higher rate loading, the specimens display rate hardening; however, the difference of stress–strain curves between the medium rate loading and QS loading before necking is quite small, it even displays noticeable negative strain rate sensitivity after necking, which can be observed clearly from the load–displacement relation shown in Figure 9 discussed later.

This unusual feature of rate softening at low stain rates can be explained by the effect of dynamic strain aging (DSA), which exists in most 5XXX series Al-Mg alloy.3 DSA is introduced from that the solute magnesium atoms lock dislocation during dislocation motion at low strain rates and sufficiently high temperature,2 which results in higher strength. As the strain rate increases, the frequency of this interaction will decrease, which results in strain rate softening in the low strain rate range. Another phenomenon indicating the DSA effect is the serration of stress–strain curve, the well-known Portevin–LeChaterlier phenomenon,17 which can be observed for both 5083-H116 and 5183 weld metal from Figure 2(a) and (c). However, the 5183 weld metal does not exhibit noticeable strain rate sensitivity in the range considered in this study.

The complex rate sensitivity of the 5XXX alloys suggests that the effect of strain rate on flow stress cannot be adequately described by the simple Johnson–Cook like constitutive laws in the range of the loading rate considered in this study. However, for the reason that DSA almost has no effect at high strain rate and since the stress–strain curves at different strain rates have similar shapes, the Johnson–Cook type models might still be applicable in the high strain rate region. Mukai et al.1 studied various Al-Mg alloys and found only when the strain rate is beyond 10 s−1, the flow stress will increase with increasing strain rate. Thus we perform calibration for Johnson–Cook model using only high loading rate data and the QS data. Figure 2(a) shows the stress–strain relation predicted by the Johnson–Cook model with C = 0.005 and ɛ·p = 180 s−1 (fitted curve) as well as the experimental curves. It should be emphasized that the Johnson–Cook model cannot predict the plasticity behavior correctly as the strain rate is less than 10 s−1. To quantify the low or negative strain rate sensitivity at the low strain rate region, further studies are required.

Compared to the AA 5XXX series, the 6082-T6 has much less magnesium concentration and no obvious DSA effect was observed in our tests (the stress–strain curves do not show serration). The stress–strain curves of 6082-T6 at high loading rate obtained from five specimens show considerable scatter. Using the mean of these dynamic stress–strain curves and the QS data, the calibrated C-value is 0.0034. Figure 2(b) gives the stress–strain relation predicted by the Johnson–Cook model with C = 0.0034 and ɛ·p = 190 s−1 as well as the experimental curves. The strain rate hardening property of 6082-T6 has been studied by other authors. Chen et al.18 conducted a series of tests at a wider strain rate range from 10−3 to 900 s−1 and found only a slight rate hardening for this material.

If the Johnson–Cook plasticity model is to be used to describe these materials, based on the limited experimental data obtained in this study, the calibrated model parameters are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Calibrated parameters for the modified Johnson–Cook plasticity model.
σ0 (MPa) n ɛ0 C q
5083-H116 189.6 0.17 0.00277 0.005 NA
6082-T6 288.7 0.064 0.00419 0.0034 1.033
5183 weld metal 113.8 0.238 0.00212 0 NA

sec.title: Temperature effect on flow stress
sec.p:
5083-H116 and 5183 weld metal exhibit similar temperature dependency of flow stress. As can be seen from Figure 4(a) and (c), before temperature is raised beyond a certain level, the flow stresses of these materials show very little variation with temperature. Clausen et al.3 also observed that the flow stress is not sensitive to temperature in the range of 20–100 ℃ for 5083-H116. As temperature continues to increase, both materials display noticeable temperature softening. Figure 4.
Comparison of the stress–strain relation predicted by the Johnson–Cook model with experimental data at different temperatures: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 6082-T6; (c) 5183 weld metal.

Because thermal softening only occurs at relatively high temperature, the Johnson–Cook plasticity model will not work in the temperature range considered in this study. By comparing the stress–strain curves at RT and at 149 ℃ for 5183 weld metal, Figure 4(c), the initial yield stress does not change much but the 149 ℃ curve show considerable less strain hardening. For this reason, stress–strain curves obtained at different temperatures for 5083-H116 and 5183 weld metal are used in the input files of the finite element analyses presented in the ‘Temperature effect on ductile failure strain’ section.

Compared to the 5XXX alloys, the temperature softening behavior of 6082-T6 can be very well described by the Johnson–Cook plasticity model at the temperature range considered in this study with a calibrated q-value of 1.033. This is manifested in Figure 4(b), where the solid lines represent the stress–strain curves obtained experimentally at 24 ℃, 66 ℃ and 149 ℃, respectively and the three dash-dotted lines represent the corresponding curves given by the Johnson–Cook plasticity model using the calibrated parameters.

sec.title: Finite element modeling and fracture criterion
sec.p: Finite element analyses of the specimens are conducted to study the fracture behavior of the materials using the software package ABAQUS.19 For round tensile specimens, axisymmetric conditions are considered and the 4-node, axisymmetric, solid elements with reduced integration (CAX4R) are used. Details of the finite element models, mesh refinement and convergence studies can be found in Gao et al.12

In the finite element modeling, ductile fracture is postulated to occur when the accumulated damage in an element reaches one. According to Hancock and Brown,6 the damage parameter can be defined as (5)D=∫0ɛ¯fdɛeqɛf(σmσeq,ɛ·p,T) where ɛf(σmσeq,ɛ·p,T) is the failure strain under the current conditions of stress state, strain rate and temperature, and ɛ¯f is the value of equivalent strain when the element finally fractures. In this study, the Johnson–Cook fracture model was adopted, and ɛf is defined as equation (2). The damage parameter defined in equation (5) accounts for the history effect when the stress triaxiality, strain rate and temperature do not remain constant.

For all the specimens in this study, fracture starts at the specimen center. Therefore, the history of stress triaxiality, plastic strain rate and equivalent strain increment of the center element are output to compute D. The sudden load drop on the measured load–displacement curve designates fracture initiation. By comparing the computed and measured load–displacement curves, the increment number at which the center element fractures can be determined. Figure 5 compares the predicted load–displacement curve with test data for 5083-H116 for the smooth tensile bar at RT and QS loading rate, where the ‘red cross’ indicates the average failure position. Figure 5.
Comparison of the numerically predicted and measured load–displacement response for the smooth tensile bars at RT and QS loading rate.
RT: room temperature; QS: quasi-static.

sec.title: Triaxiality effect on failure strain
sec.p: As described in the Johnson–Cook fracture model, the triaxiality-dependent, rate-dependent and temperature-dependent terms in equation (2) are not coupled, thus the calibration of the parameters D1 to D5 can be performed separately. We first calibrate the parameters D1 to D3 using the RT, QS data.

Figure 6 compares the predicted load–displacement curves with experimental records for the notched round bars, where the solid black lines represent the experimental measurements and the dashed red lines represent the numerical predictions. In general, the numerical results match the experimental records very well. For 5083-H116, the FEA results slightly over-predicted the load-displacement responses as the notch radius get smaller. A possible explanation is that the plasticity behavior of this material might be pressure dependent, which is not accounted for in the analyses presented here. Figure 6.
Comparison of the predicted and measured load–displacement responses for the notched round bars at room temperature and QS loading rate: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 6082-T6; (c) 5183 weld metal.
QS: quasi-static.

A nonlinear optimization process is employed to determine parameters D1 to D3, where an optimization function is chosen as to minimize the difference between the average of the computed damage values and one (6)min(D1,D2,D3)(Error)=min(D1,D2,D3)1N∑i=1N[1-Df(i)]2 where N is the number of specimens and Df(i) is the computed damage parameter value for specimen i using equation (5) with the assumed values of D1, D2 and D3. A Matlab program using the Nelded–Mead simplex method20 was written to optimize the error function for finding best fit parameters.

For round tensile specimens, failure starts at the specimen center. As can be seen in Figure 7, the variation of stress triaxiality in the center element is not very large during the loading process for several specimens. A simple way to obtain an initial guess of parameters (D1,D2,D3) is to average the stress triaxiality during the loading history up to fracture initiation, σavg*=1ɛ¯f∫0ɛ¯fσmσeqdɛeq, and fit the (σavg*,ɛ¯f) points obtained for the smooth and notched specimens into a function in the form expressed as the first bracket of equation (2). Figure 7.
Variation of the stress triaxiality in the center element during the loading history: (a) 5083-H116 smooth roundbar; (b) 5083-H116 B-notch.

The calibrated D1 to D3 values from the optimization process described above are listed in Table 4. Figure 8 shows the variation of effective failure strain with stress triaxiality at RT and QS loading, where the solid line represents the function form with the calibrated parameters (D1, D2, D3) and the symbols represent the effective failure strain and the corresponding average stress triaxiality for the smooth and three notched tensile specimens respectively. It can be observed that for all three materials, failure strain is a decay function of the stress triaxiality. For the 5183 weld metal, due to the material variability introduced by the welding process, a larger scatter in strain to failure was observed in the experiments. Figure 8.
Effective failure strain vs. stress triaxiality at room temperature, QS loading rate: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 6082-T6; (c) 5183 weld metal.
Table 4.
Calibrated parameters for the Johnson–Cook fracture model.
D1 D2 D3 D4 D5
5083-H116 –0.785 1.133 –0.229 0.0897 7.970
6082-T6 0.0164 2.245 –2.798 0.0070 3.658
5183 weld metal –0.900 1.185 –0.128 0.0975 9.584

It is important to point out that the parameter D1 calibrated above does not represent a limit value for ductility. As described by Johnson and Cook,15 the function form of ɛf versus σmσeq given by the first bracket of equation (2) is only valid for triaxiality level lower than 1.5, they also mentioned that the fracture strain varies approximately in a linear manner from the value at σmσeq=1.5 to a minimum value ɛf(min) corresponding to the spall stress.

sec.title: Strain rate effect on ductile failure strain
sec.p: Similar to the plastic flow behavior, the variation of the failure strain with strain rate is not monotonic for 5083-H116. As shown in Figure 9, the 5083-H116 specimens tested at the intermediate loading rates exhibit lower elongation than those tested quasi-statically. In the strain rate range where DSA works, the negative strain rate hardening will lead to strain localization,21 which results in higher probability of failure and thus decreases the ductility. The high inhomogeneity of plastic flow at the intermediate strain rate could be a possible explanation of the lower ductility than QS loading.22

At high strain rate, the ductility of 5083-H116 increases significantly. From the picture of the fractured specimens shown in Figure 10, a transition from a slant fracture surface at low rate to a cup-cone fracture surface at high rate is observed, which indicates the change of failure mechanism with the increasing loading rate. The cup-cone fracture surface is a result of the void formation, growth and coalescence mechanism while the slant fracture surface is caused by shear failure. This change of failure mechanism is also demonstrated by the microscopic pictures of fracture surface given by Mukai et al.1 for a high purity aluminum alloy with 5% Magnesium, which show that the void size does not change much as the strain rate increases from 10−4 to 2 s−1, but the voids grow to much larger sizes at the strain rate of 1.5 × 103. Figure 9.
Compares of the level 1 (QS) and level 2 (strain rate < 1 s−1) load vs. engineering strain curves for 5083-H116 smooth specimens tested at room temperature.
QS: quasi-static.
Figure 10.
Fractured 5083-H116 specimens tested at room temperature and various loading rates: (a) quasi-static; (b) intermediate rate; (c) high rate.

Because the fracture behavior of 5083-H116 at the intermediate loading rate is very complex, here we only perform FEA at the level 3 loading rate. The Johnson–Cook plasticity model with the calibrated parameters given in the section ‘Strain rate effect on flow stress’ is incorporated into ABAQUS via a user defined subroutine and used in the dynamic analysis.

In the high rate tests, engineering strains in the gage section were measured using strain gages. As the applied load approaches the maximum value, necking develops in the gage section, resulting the strain gage failure due to the following two scenarios: (1) If necking occurs at the spot where the strain gage was placed, the strain gage may debond from the specimen after necking develops; (2) If necking occurs at a location other than where the strain gage was placed, the readings of the strain gage will not reflect the post-necking deformation experienced by the specimen. Consequently, the experimental records do not have the complete deformation history and we cannot determine the failure point from the load–displacement records. Instead, we will use the load versus time records to find the instant when failure initiates (sudden load drop).

The FEA of each specimen involves an iterative process. We vary the applied velocity at the specimen ends until the computed engineering strain versus time of the gage section matches the experimental records. The experimental data suggest that the engineering strain rate in the gage section gradually increases to a constant value. Figure 11(a) to (f) compare the computed load versus time and engineering strain (gage section) versus time histories with experimental records for the smooth round bars of the three materials tested at RT under level 3 dynamic loading. Figure 11.
Comparison of the computed load vs. time and gage section displacement vs. time histories with experimental records for the smooth round bar at room temperature and level 3 dynamic loading: (a, b) 5083-H116; (c, d) 6082-T6; (e, f) 5183 weld metal.

Using the level 3 dynamic test data and the optimization procedure described above, the parameter D4 is calibrated as 0.0897, 0.007 and 0.0975 for 5083-H116, 6082-T6 and the 5183 weld metal, respectively. A positive D4 indicates that the failure strain becomes larger as the strain rate increases. Compared to the significant increasing of ductile failure strain at high strain rates, the D4 value is quite small which indicates that 6082-T6 has very low rate sensitivity on ductility.

sec.title: Temperature effect on ductile failure strain
sec.p:
Figure 12 shows the load versus displacement curves for 5XXX series smooth specimens tested at 66 ℃ and 24 ℃ under QS loading. At each temperature, several specimens were tested and only the specimens exhibiting least and most ductility were shown in Figure 12. It is clear that the ductility is lower at 66 ℃. However, the ductility of 5XXX at 149 ℃ is much higher than at 24 ℃, which can be seen from Figures 13(a) and (c). Based on the research of Skinner et al.22 on different aluminum alloys where DSA effect exists, minimum ductility occurs at intermediate temperatures. At elevated temperatures two mechanisms affect ductility and flow behavior: dynamic recovery results in lower strength and higher ductility whereas the DSA effect is opposite. At lower elevated temperature (66 ℃), the DSA has a strong effect, which results in lower ductility. However, at higher elevated temperature (149 ℃), the dynamic recovery dominates and serration of stress–strain curve is not observed. Figure 12.
Comparison of the QS load vs. displacement curves for smooth specimens tested at 66 ℃ than 24 ℃: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 5183 weld metal.
QS: quasi-static.
Figure 13.
Comparison of the predicted and measured load–displacement responses for tests at different temperatures: (a) 5083-H116; (b) 6082-T6; (c) 5183 weld metal.

From the above discussions, the Johnson–Cook fracture model is not suitable for the 5XXX alloys in the temperature range considered. The calibrated D5 values in Table 4 for the 5XXX alloys are from data tested at RT and at 149 ℃, which only serve for comparison of the temperature effect on ductility of different materials.

In contrast to the 5XXX series, the ductility of 6082-T6 increases as temperature increase monotonically as shown in Figure 13(b), and the failure strain of this material can be very well predicted by the Johnson–Cook fracture model.

The parameter D5 is calibrated as 7.970, 3.658 and 9.584 for 5083-H116, 6082-T6 and the 5183 weld metal respectively. A positive D5 indicates that the failure strain becomes larger as temperature increases, and 6082-T6 shows less ductility changing compared to other two materials. Figure 13 also compares the computed and the experimentally measured load–displacement curves of the smooth round tensile specimen tested at different temperatures.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p:
In this study, the effects of strain rate and temperature on the plastic response and ductile failure strain of three aluminum alloys often used in marine structures, AA 5083-H116, AA 6082-T6 and AA 5183 weld metal, are investigated. As a first step, the applicability of the Johnson–Cook plasticity and ductile fracture models is examined. The primary findings can be summarized as follows:
Flow stress and failure strain of AA 5083-H116 show negative strain rate dependency at low dynamic loading rate (< 1 s−1) at RT, which is strongly related to the DSA effect. But at high strain rate, this material exhibits rate hardening and significant increase in ductility.
The flow stress of the 5183 weld metal is not sensitive to the strain rate, whereas the ductility increases significantly at high strain rate.
At RT the flow stress of AA 6082-T6 displays strain rate hardening effect while the ductility increase at high strain rate is insignificant.
Before the temperature is raised beyond a certain level, the QS flow stresses of AA 5083-H116 and the 5183 weld metal show no obvious temperature dependency but the ductilities of these alloys are lower at 66 ℃ than at 24 ℃. As temperature continues to increase, both materials display noticeable temperature softening and increase of ductility.
Both temperature softening and increase of failure strain with elevating temperature of AA 6082-T6 can be well described by the Johnson–Cook plasticity and fracture models.
For all three materials, the equivalent strain to failure is a decaying function of the stress triaxiality and a nonlinear optimization procedure is used to calibrate the parameters involved in this function.

Our results show that the strain-rate-dependent and temperature-dependent relations given by the Johnson–Cook plasticity and fracture models generally are not applicable for the AA 5XXX series especially in the temperature and loading rate range where DSA effect exists. However the Johnson–Cook plasticity model may be applicable when temperature and loading rate exceed certain levels, or can be modified as a concaved strain rate sensitivity function. To develop more accurate and useful mathematical relations for rate and temperature dependencies of these materials requires further experimental and numerical work to be conducted.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Office of naval Research [grant number N00014-08-1-0688].
